turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: We'll hear argument first this term in Case 09-907, Ransom v. FIA Card Services.
Mr. Burke.

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
In 2005 when Congress passed the Bankruptcy Act, it made a policy decision to limit judicial discretion on a case-by-case basis in the area of reasonable and necessary expenses.
It did so by creating a formula that entails an aggregate set amount of expenses for an individual.
Now, Congress could have created this from scratch.
It could have used an arbitrary figure.
But instead, there are figures that the IRS already had, based on Census Bureau statistics, that said nationwide, in a certain area, an individual would spend this much a month on average.
In the case of Mr. Ransom, that's approximately 2500 a month.

Forgetting about how it's divided up, if I had 100 people come in and answer the following five questions the same way Mr. Ransom did, and that's age, location, household size, gross income, and if you have a vehicle, how many, they would all get $2,500 standard aggregate deduction, which works out to $150,000 over a five-year period.
Now, the crux of this is whether or not courts are allowed to dig in and cut out pieces of the standard aggregate amount.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: Why is that the crux of it?
Congress made reference to the local standards, right?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: And were the -- was the commentary in the Collection Financial Standards in existence at the time when Congress enacted this provision?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: There was a Collection Financial Analysis that was in place, and it was noted in 1998 as a prior version of the bill that ultimately wasn't passed.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: And that explains what the IRS understands the local standards to mean; isn't that right?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: I would disagree with that.
I would say -- well, it would -- it would explain what the IRS means, but that's where I would end it, because the IRS standards are used to collect taxes.
They are discretionary.
They--

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I understand that, but Congress decided to make reference to the local standards in this bankruptcy provision, didn't it?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: --Standards.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: It didn't go beyond that.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: And this -- and at the time when it did that, there was official IRS commentary regarding the meaning of those standards, correct?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: For the IRS to use in collecting taxes.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: And your argument is that Congress intended to adopt the standards promulgated by the IRS, but not the IRS's interpretation of the standards.

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: Correct, not their methodology or interpretation.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Doesn't the chart say "ownership costs"?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And you would read that to mean non-costs as well?
I mean, if the -- if the table is called ownership costs, then why not use the IRS's definition of what costs are; and that definition says what, loan payments and lease payments?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: Because we have to look at it as a standard aggregate.
And what I mean by that is -- okay, the Bankruptcy Code doesn't define ownership costs.
And ownership costs could be the replacement value.
It could be buying a new vehicle.
It could be the costs associated with making payments on a vehicle.
What that -- that average number is, in this case, $471, is a nationwide figure that somebody would spend on average in a month.
It doesn't mean that any one individual spends that amount.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Burke, isn't it the -- isn't it the case that, even on the other side's interpretation of it, it doesn't come down to actual costs anyway?
Isn't it the case, or do I misunderstand it, that so long as there is one payment, you get the entire deduction?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: That's their position, or even $1.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Even one payment of $1, you get the entire deduction.
So to argue this case as though it's a question of whether you actually expend the money that you are getting the credit for is simply -- is simply false.
You don't do that under either side's interpretation, right?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: Again, I would perhaps--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I'm trying to help you, Mr. Burke.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Burke, before you respond to that question, isn't it so that in the event that Justice Scalia just proposed, the trustee could propose an amendment to the plan to reflect that that cost is no longer being incurred?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: --The cost has never been incurred.
That's the point.
And--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: My question is: In the situation that Justice Scalia proposed, it's not automatic that this $471 gets deducted because there could be proposed an amendment of the claim to reflect that that -- there is no longer any expense for ownership.

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: --In the situation where there is a dollar, of course, an amendment can be made.
But the -- the dollar doesn't show up in the means test.
The means test is the aggregate--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But it isn't -- it isn't automatic that because there's one payment, then forever, the rest of the 5 years, he gets to deduct the $471.

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: --That's what the lower court said.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Excuse me.
What -- what happens under the tax law?
Do they make an adjustment under the tax law as well?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: Under the tax law you get a standard deduction.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: A standard--

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: No different than here.
Nobody goes behind the scenes and says, hey, what is that standard deduction?

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Right.

So that they -- what is suggested is that you look at it and apply the IRS's approach as to whether you get into the chart, but then you don't use the IRS's approach when the trustee takes you out of the chart.
Is that what you think is the law?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: No, that is not what I think is the law.
What I'm saying is Congress has given, in this case, an individual like Jason Ransom $150,000 over five years to spend.
They are not saying whether he actually spends it in any one category.
For instance, the car ownership might equate to $28,000 over 5 years.
Rent might be 1,000.
That's 60,000 over 5 years.
Congress did not say, go back and make sure Mr. Ransom is spending every dollar.
These are averages across the nation.
And when it comes to a car ownership expense, we are not saying spend $471.
Oh, you have no payment?
You didn't spend anything for 5 years?
No.

What it's saying is over 5 years I have a cost associated with owning that vehicle, whether it's a loan or lease payment, whether it's replacing the vehicle, whether it's major repairs, on average, across the country.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: You do.
You do, but the difficulty that I -- I don't get the answer to Justice Ginsburg's first question.
Of course you have all kinds of costs dealing with ownership, but what the IRS says, what it says in the statute, is you are supposed to take the applicable costs from IRS.
And what it has on page 5a is it has something called ownership costs.

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And it defines those as $471.

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And then on 3a, where it says what ownership costs are, it says
"The transportation standards consist of nationwide figures for monthly loan or lease payments, referred to as ownership costs. "
So when I read that, I said: Ownership costs means monthly loan or lease payments, nothing else.
Now, you have all kinds of other things.
It's just these words "ownership costs" don't refer to those other things, because of that definition given right there.
That's what I thought Justice Ginsburg was initially asking.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Yes, I was.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And -- and how do you get out of that what I think of as very, very clear language which says what these standards refer to?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: Because the standards refer to the numbers.
It's a chart.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes, but it doesn't -- for example, suppose you buy a dozen apples every month and they cost you $48 extra.
You are not going to say the ownership costs refer to the apples, even if you decorate the car with them.

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: What -- what--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I mean, ownership costs refers to lease and loan payments.
Nothing else.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What's the language we are dealing with, Mr. Burke?
Do you want to quote the language to us?
Nobody's quoted the language.
What does it say is applicable?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: --What the statute says is the applicable -- you shall get, mandatory, the applicable amounts specified based on where the debtor resides.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Wait.
The -- the applicable amounts specified where?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: In the national local standards.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Read the text of the statute, would you, please, for me?
I couldn't even get it from your brief.
You had to refer me back to the petition.
Why isn't an appendix to your brief or printed in the beginning of your brief, instead of kicking me back to dig out your petition.

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: "The debtor's monthly expenses shall be the debtor's applicable monthly expense amount specified under the national local standards. "

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: "Amount specified under" the standard.

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: Specific amount, "applicable modified amount specified".

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: "Applicable amount specified", not the "amount specified if applicable".

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: Correct, based on where a debtor resides.
Now, the only way a court can say that an individual has to have a debt on a car to get this deduction -- two ways: One--

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: Look at the local standard, which is on page 8 of the appendix to your brief, right?
And all it says is
"Ownership costs, first car, $471. "
That's the relevant text, isn't it.

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: What if a person leases a car?
Do you think they get ownership costs?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: Yes, because they get the cost whether they owe on it or not.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: But they don't own the car, so how can they get ownership costs?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: There's a different definition.
Ownership doesn't mean -- it can mean possession.
But--

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: Where do you get that, from the--

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: --From the--

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: --The Collection Financial Standards?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: --The Collection Financial Standards say you get the lease -- you get the deduction if you have a loan or a lease payment.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: Where do you get the definition that somebody who leases something owns it?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: I don't.
I'm not sure they do own it.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: Then how do they get ownership costs?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: Because you have possession of it.
It's based on having the item, costs associated with having the item, whether it's paid off or not.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: If somebody rents an apartment, do they own the apartment?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: Probably under ownership, their possession is some type of an ownership, maybe just possessory.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Is there something wrong with the IRS saying what they mean?
It says
"Ownership costs means monthly loan or lease payments. "
Now, is there something--

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: The problem--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --That's what it says it means.
Now, is there something illegal about it defining ownership costs in that way?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: --No, for collection of taxes there is not.

But if you're going to use -- start digging into the manual, you might as well bring it all in to 707(b), and, as we discussed earlier, there was language that said the collection financial analysis should be brought in, but that was deleted in the final version.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Why not -- it says you are suppose to look at the costs; it's ownership costs.
So the only thing you'd look at the IRS for is, the manual, is to define ownership costs.
And they say ownership costs means those two things.

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: There is no reason to limit it.
If you are going to -- the text doesn't say -- it says national local standards.
It doesn't discriminate or give disparate treatment to that one item.
If you are going to give it to one item, then it can be pulled in, and it should be -- the same treatment should be given to all items, and we should have to prove some type of a--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: I don't follow that.
If the simple thing is to just -- what does the word "costs" mean?
And then you look to the IRS manual and it tells you that the cost means loan or lease payments.

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: --To collect taxes, that's how they defined it.
But in the statute it says you get "local standard amount specified".
It does not stretch it and say IRS's interpretation> ["].
That language was taken out.
And if we were to use the IRS interpretation, here's the whole problem: It's discretionary.
It goes up and down.
It's based on an IRS revenue agent.
It -- let me give you a separate example--

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: Mr. Burke, if we could stay with this.
The $471 is derived by looking at the average loan or lease payments nationwide.
Then in addition to that we know that the IRS has a separate category for operating costs that is meant to reflect costs of having a car that are not your loan and lease payments.

So between those two things, why wouldn't we say that ownership costs means your loan and lease payments, but operating costs means your other costs of having a car, and that you get the operating costs if you have a car but don't make loan and lease payments and you get the ownership costs if you do make loan and lease payments?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: --Because to reach that you have to go into the Internal Revenue Manual.
It's not in the statute that says you have to owe on it to get it.
And if you go into the Internal Revenue Manual -- let's look at operating expenses.
What it says, in collecting taxes, and it's in the Joint Appendix at page 83 through 88.
But what it says when it comes to local national and other expenses, an internal revenue agent has discretion.
You only get these expenses -- this is the overall idea -- if they produce income or if it's for health and welfare.

So when we look at the Joint Appendix page 88, section (b), under the local standard transportation expenses, when it talks about operating costs, which is something you just mentioned, it says you only get transportation expenses that are used to produce income for the health and welfare of an individual and their family.
Plus, the fact that you own a car, the IRS under its discretion can take away the operating costs if it's on four cinder blocks in your backyard.
You are not incurring fuel costs, mileage costs, you are not paying probably registration or any of those other operating costs.
The IRS agent under their manual can take away that expense.
So why stop and say, well, we're just going to look at the ownership costs, and all they're saying here is if you owe on it you get it, if you don't owe you don't get it.
Let's not look at anything else in the Internal Revenue Manual, which is a 39 part, 500 page document that in some ways is almost incomprehensible, and--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Burke, the -- it's unusual to allow a deduction for the purpose of calculating disposable income although you don't have any expense.
I understand how you get to that conclusion with respect to car ownership.
Is there any other provision that in calculating disposable income you are allowed a deduction for an expense that you don't incur?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: --If the Court understands my view that Congress gave--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: No.
The question, is there anything else that works like this?
You don't have the expense, nonetheless you have the deduction?
Any -- I mean, there are a whole list of deductions, expenses.
Is there any other one that works this way?
It doesn't matter whether you have the expense, in fact.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: For example, Mr. Burke, what would happen if you didn't actually have any out-of-pocket medical costs?
Could you still claim a deduction for out-of-pocket medical costs?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: --I'm saying you get all the deductions, whether you owe on it or not.
Is there a specific one besides the car ownership that says you have to owe on it?
No.
But my point is--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Is that the general view of the courts?
Is the answer that you just gave supported uniformly by the courts that have looked at this?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: --There is about 60 published cases.
They are split almost 50-50, actually more--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: In other words, even on this point they are split?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: --This is one line that they have looked at in the cases.
Basically--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I don't understand what you are saying.
He asked are they split 50-50 on the point that is before us here, yes or no.

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: --Yes, they're split about 50-50.

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: Do they apply -- do the Courts apply the housing and utilities listed amount whether or not you pay for a house or not, whether or not you rent?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: There's two published cases I'm aware of and both allowed it.
One, somebody had military housing; one, the house was paid off.
Both courts said you get it under the local standards.
But the IRS manual would not give that to you, because under the local standards the IRS manual says you get the specific amount or your actual payment, whatever is less.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Of course, once again, Mr. Burke, this is -- I don't know why you don't point this out.
This is not the difference between your position and the position of the other side.
You get the deduction for the other side as well, whether or not you are making the payment.

Now, maybe it can be adjusted by the trustee, but as far as the statute is concerned, so long as you make one payment of one dollar, under their theory you are entitled to claim the deduction; isn't that right.

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: My question, incidentally, about courts was not with reference to the car expense.

It was in reference to the hypothetical or to the issue proposed by one of my colleagues, that said, Justice Kagan, suppose you don't have the medical expense, and the answer -- and your -- and I wanted to know if your answer is supported uniformly by the courts that have looked at this or if there is also a split on that point?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: I apologize for not understanding it.
No, every other expense deduction that I have seen besides the car ownership, somebody gets it.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: And they get it whether or not they incur that expense or not?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: In other words, food, you don't have to say, well, he did spend this much money on food, so he gets the same deduction?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: If he doesn't eat as much as somebody else he gets the same deduction, right?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: Right.
Or if he lives at home and mom cooks for him.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: But, Mr. Burke, even you would say -- is this correct -- that if you don't own a car at all you can't claim the car costs?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Is that -- is that by reason of the Internal Revenue Service--

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --manual or is it by reason of the Bankruptcy Code itself?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: It's by reason of the Bankruptcy Code that refers to the standards and the standards specifically say, you have one car, no cars and you get a public transportation, or two cars; pick the one.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So it's in the chart--

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: It's in the chart.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --that you claim -- okay.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: What if you own a car but it's completely inoperable and it has no value.
You buy it for a dollar.
It's a junk car and you are planning possibly to restore it at some point.
Do you get the deduction then?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: Based on a strict reading of the code, you get it.
Now, would the IRS allow it?
Again, that's a discretionary standard, but any time you have an objective test there's going to be line-drawing and perceived unfairness on the outskirts.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And would your answer be the same if the allowance was set, the decree was made, and the debtor then went out and bought the junker to put in his driveway just in order to get the 400-plus dollars a month, or would that be deemed an evasion of the law that could be addressed by the Bankruptcy Court?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: It can addressed by the Bankruptcy Court, and that's the beauty of the statute.
We don't need to go into the Internal Revenue Manual.
We just need their tables, because there is a provision, 1325(a)(3), that deals with good faith.
So it appears somebody is not acting in good faith, then--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: What is -- we've got about half the courts in the country agreeing with you.
And so you've read all those arguments, and what in your opinion is the best one on the point, again, where I am stuck, which is Justice Ginsburg's original point.
I mean, I can think of millions of examples.
You have a form that says the employer says entertainment expenses and it defines entertainment expenses as food and transport, and they leave out movies, you know.
Or you could have vacation expenses and vacation expenses are defined as transport and hotel, and they leave out meals.
And here we have a definition of ownership expenses and they say leasing and loaning and they leave out other forms of ownership.

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: --Because--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Now, the argument is, well, that's what they mean by it, so that's what applicable.
Now, what's the best argument against that in those 50 cases?
Why is it trying -- why to try to get an expense which isn't loan or lease?
Have you any more right to it than if you tried to get an expense to my totally irrelevant apples?
I mean, it doesn't fit within the applicable definition.
What's the answer?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: --The means test is a form, and if you look at the form -- the means test is a form.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I've looked at the form.

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: If you look at the form, it just says--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Ownership.

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: --That's it.
There's no definition in the form.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Two pages earlier they say what they mean by the word "ownership".

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: Not the -- the IRS does.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: Not the statute and not the B-22 form that is filled out by debtors.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Half the courts say, oh, you just sort of imagine what ownership expenses are and anything that they can fall within that general English language word is what they can deduct; is that their approach?
Because if you go longer you say cut off the definition, cut off the definition from the word "ownership", don't use it.
So what do we use to define what ownership is?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: We don't have to.
Congress gave standard amounts for--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I know, but it's for ownership, it's not for, for example, whistling; it's for ownership.
So how do we define what that $471 attaches to?
Do we use a State common law definition or something?
How have they done it?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: --Because you can take it as a bunch of variables.
It's not in the Bankruptcy Code.
So it could be replacement costs, it could be major repairs.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Is this a problem distinctive to your case?
Doesn't the other side have the same problem with ownership?
Don't they acknowledge that even if you are leasing the car you get the deduction?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I don't see why this is distinctive to your case.
It's a problem both sides face.
And we don't avoid it by coming out against you, do we?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: No, we don't.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Why?

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: What if -- what if the definition of--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Why don't we?

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: --ownership costs was moved into the local standards themselves?
Would the outcome be different then.

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: Are you saying in 707(b)?

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: No.
It's moved from the CFS to the local standards, which are referred to in the code provision.

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: My answer would still be the same because that's not a congressional formula.
That's a form that comes off the Department of Justice website which administers the U.S. Trustee's program and that's their litigation position.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: But, Mr. Burke, if the table said loan and lease costs, you wouldn't have a case?
If it said, instead of ownership costs, if it said loan and lease costs, then you would sit down and you would say I'm not entitled to that deduction?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: No.
I would say an individual who owns a car, whether they owe or not, gets the deduction because it's part of this aggregate standard.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: Even if it's called loan and lease costs?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: Correct.
It's not a breakdown on what any one individual has.
It's an aggregate.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: You may want to save the rest of your time for rebuttal.

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: Thank you, I will.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, counsel.
Ms. Maynard.

turn.speaker: deanne_e_maynard
turn.label: Ms. Deanne E. Maynard
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
The Bankruptcy Code precludes an above-median income debtor like Petitioner from shielding from his creditors $471 a month for a car payment that he does not have.
A debtor with--

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: --food costs, housing costs, utility costs, by getting his parents to pay for those things and still take this deduction?

turn.speaker: deanne_e_maynard
turn.label: Ms. Deanne E. Maynard
turn.text: --The statute allows a debtor to take an applicable monthly expense amount.
So if the debtor truly has no food costs, then the food standard would be not applicable to the debtor.

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: Your adversary said that only two courts have addressed this issue and have permitted those deductions.
So under what reasoning would we apply a different standard to the car costs as opposed to those other costs?

turn.speaker: deanne_e_maynard
turn.label: Ms. Deanne E. Maynard
turn.text: Well, I think with respect, I think the cases we were talking about were housing.

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: Housing.

turn.speaker: deanne_e_maynard
turn.label: Ms. Deanne E. Maynard
turn.text: Right.
So housing and car costs are part of the local standards.
Food, clothing, house cleaning supplies, those are part of the national standards.

The -- in our view, the text that goes along with, accompanies the tables, which is not the Internal Revenue Manual, it's just the pages reprinted at 1-A to 3-A of our brief, the Collection Financial Standards, the prefatory explanation for what the tables mean.
In our view, that goes along and is incorporated into the national local standards.
The national standards, Justice Sotomayor, are allowed.

As long as you have under the calculations as explained in the standards, under the national standards, a debtor would receive the allowance in the table as long as they have any such expense, so regardless of amount.
However, if they have no such expense, then they are taken out by the statutory language in the means test, which says that the standard must be applicable to the debtor.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: So if they have prepurchased their food expenses, so long as they have one dollar of food expense they get the entire expense even though they are not incurring it?

turn.speaker: deanne_e_maynard
turn.label: Ms. Deanne E. Maynard
turn.text: If they are--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: And there are things like, you can pay up, you know, have the grocery deliver your food every month and you can pay in advance, and if you paid up you still get the full food expense that is allowed?

turn.speaker: deanne_e_maynard
turn.label: Ms. Deanne E. Maynard
turn.text: --No, Your Honor.

I think if over the 60-month period looking forward you know that you're going to -- you've already paid up for your food for the next 60 months and you are not going to incur any additional food expenses, no, then in that situation the standard would be inapplicable to you.
You would be having now -- in that hypothetical--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: But if you paid 1 dollar for food you would get the full amount for 60 months?

turn.speaker: deanne_e_maynard
turn.label: Ms. Deanne E. Maynard
turn.text: --Under the standard.
That's the way the standards operate, Your Honor.
I haven't seen any cases litigated--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: So your argument leads to a result that is just as absurd as your colleague's result on the other side.

turn.speaker: deanne_e_maynard
turn.label: Ms. Deanne E. Maynard
turn.text: --I don't believe so, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: I mean, that was a big part of your argument.
You said his position leads to an absurd result, and yours is just as absurd.

turn.speaker: deanne_e_maynard
turn.label: Ms. Deanne E. Maynard
turn.text: I don't think so, Your Honor, for this reason, which is that the national standards are food, clothing, house cleaning supplies, things that you expect every debtor to have.
You don't see much litigation about those expenses.
The local standards, however, operate differently.
In our view -- and our view's different from the Government's, Justice Scalia.

In our view, under the local standards and the way that they apply as explained in the Collection Financial Standards, is that the debtor is allowed their actual expense for the local standard or the amount in the table, whichever is less.
So in the hypothetical--

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: Where does it say that?

turn.speaker: deanne_e_maynard
turn.label: Ms. Deanne E. Maynard
turn.text: --In our--

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: The debtor's monthly expenses shall be the debtor's applicable monthly expense amount specified under the national and local standards.
So the national and local standards have amounts listed.
Where does it say you take only the actual, not the national or local standards?

turn.speaker: deanne_e_maynard
turn.label: Ms. Deanne E. Maynard
turn.text: --I read that text, Your Honor -- again, the Court doesn't need to decide this maximum cap issue to decide this case, because the Petitioner has no expense whatsoever and so it's not applicable to him.
But in our view, Justice Sotomayor -- in our view you get it from the language of the statute that says
"the debtor's applicable monthly expense amount specified under the national standards and local standards. "
And the way that we understand the national and local standards to work is, if you look at page -- it's explained on page 1A of the petition to our brief, the red brief.
Maximum allowance -- it's the third paragraph down:
"Maximum allowances for housing and utilities and transportation, known as the local standards, vary by location. "
"Unlike the national standards, the taxpayer is allowed the amount actually spent or the standard, whichever is less. "

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: But that's -- but that's not what the provision at issue here says.
It says you use the amount specified under the national standards and you use actual for everything else.
That's what the statute says.
So now you are trying to move the actual into the first half of the test?

turn.speaker: deanne_e_maynard
turn.label: Ms. Deanne E. Maynard
turn.text: No, Your Honor, that's not how I understand the text.
The text provides--

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: Why would you even bother?
Why don't you -- if -- if what you are arguing is that only actual expenses are -- are what you can claim, you wouldn't need the first half.

turn.speaker: deanne_e_maynard
turn.label: Ms. Deanne E. Maynard
turn.text: --Yes, you would, Your Honor, because what the -- what the statute's purpose here is -- I mean, I think it's helpful to step back.
Chapter 13 sends one to chapter 7's means test for the purpose of calculating the amounts reasonably necessary for the maintenance and support of the debtor.

And Congress chose to import the -- the methodology of the national standards and local standards as a way both to set the categories of expenses that debtors could receive payment for, and, with the case of the national and local standards, to set the amounts.

They were worried about capping upper discretion because Congress, it's quite clear from the text and the legislative history, was concerned about above-medium-income debtors taking luxurious expense amounts.

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: So what you would have the statute read is: The debtor's monthly expenses shall be the debtor's applicable monthly expense amount specified, as a -- as a maximum.
You would have to add "maximum" somewhere there.

turn.speaker: deanne_e_maynard
turn.label: Ms. Deanne E. Maynard
turn.text: No, Your Honor, because the amount under the national standards as the national standards operate is the -- is an allowance, not an actual, and the amount under the local standards as they operate is the amount actually spent or the amount in the table, whichever is less.
Again--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Your -- your position penalizes debtors who pay their expenses in advance, who don't incur additional debt to pay for things like their car.

I would have thought the Bankruptcy Code would think that's a good thing, that they are not incurring debt that they can't afford to pay off, but instead, to the extent they can, they are paying expenses in advance.
Why should somebody who does that be in a worse position than somebody -- somebody who takes out a loan they can't afford to pay back?

turn.speaker: deanne_e_maynard
turn.label: Ms. Deanne E. Maynard
turn.text: --Money is fungible, Your Honor, so to the extent the debtor has incurred expenses before going into bankruptcy instead of, as here, paying off this more than $85,000 in credit card debt--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Well, he hasn't incurred -- he hasn't incurred expenses.
It's the whole point, I guess, that he's paid for something.

turn.speaker: deanne_e_maynard
turn.label: Ms. Deanne E. Maynard
turn.text: --He used his money, perhaps, to purchase his car outright, instead of to pay down his credit card debt, and so he has a salary of $50,000, and he has a credit card debt of $85,000, and he owns a 2-year car -- 2-year-old car outright.

He should not be able to deduct, as a measure of his reasonably necessary expenses for his maintenance and support over the next 50 months, $28,000 that he doesn't need for a car payment that he doesn't make.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: You're--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Even though he can do it -- even though he can do it for everything else: he can do it for food, he can do it for housekeeping expenses, he can do it for personal care expenses, he can even do it -- the other, the final category is miscellaneous, so he can do it for anything.

turn.speaker: deanne_e_maynard
turn.label: Ms. Deanne E. Maynard
turn.text: Well, the miscellaneous, all those numbers are capped, and the legislative history makes clear Congress thought all those numbers would actually effectively act as caps.
In other words, to the extent there was debate in the Congress, Congress was concerned that these numbers were actually too low, not that they were going to give anybody a windfall.
But to the extent--

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: So what you are proposing is that every debtor has to go to the Bankruptcy Court and show what their monthly food bills have been over what period of time, how much their personal supplies have been over what period of time?
How can you calculate forward what they are going to spend on a monthly basis for each of those items?
Isn't that the reason the tables are used, so that you don't have to do that?

turn.speaker: deanne_e_maynard
turn.label: Ms. Deanne E. Maynard
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor, and in the national standard, which all the items you just list are national standards, under the national standards you don't do the actuals.
On page 1A it explains:
"Allowances for food, clothing and other items, known as the national standards, apply nationwide except for Alaska and Hawaii. "
"Taxpayers are allowed the total national standards amount for their family size and income level without questioning amounts actually spent. "
For -- yes, for those hard-to-calculate items, you do -- our position is you do get the amounts in the chart.

For local standards, the local standards, however, which include home, mortgage, lease expenses, utilities and transportation, which include both ownership costs and operating costs, you get the actual or whichever is less.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I must say your position is more logical than the position that you read in some of the instructions applicable to the -- to the chart that's referred to in the Bankruptcy Code, but not others.

I mean, it seems to me, if you are going to read in the requirement that have to have made a lease payment, you should also read in the requirement that you are referring to now, which would mean your deduction is limited by the -- by the amount of your lease payment.
I don't see why -- is there any reason why one would read in the other one and not read in yours?

turn.speaker: deanne_e_maynard
turn.label: Ms. Deanne E. Maynard
turn.text: Not in our view, Your Honor, because in our view the chart is -- is ambiguous about what the numbers stand for.
And so in the national standards, the text, the prefatory text, explains that the amount is an allowance if you have the expense.
In the local standards the prefatory text explains that the amount operates as a cap.
But the important point for this case, Your Honor, is that you don't have to decide anything about the national standards because Petitioner is left at the statutory door.
He has no applicable monthly expense amount for operating--

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: Ms. Maynard, what would happen if the debtor had a car that was 200,000 miles old -- 200,000 miles, and it was going to break down, you know, within the next 5 years?
Would the debtor then be able to take the deduction?

turn.speaker: deanne_e_maynard
turn.label: Ms. Deanne E. Maynard
turn.text: --If the debtor owns the car outright at the time they file for bankruptcy, they would not get the deduction.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: Even though if you look ahead, if you project forward, it's pretty clear that the debtor is going to have to incur those expenses?

turn.speaker: deanne_e_maynard
turn.label: Ms. Deanne E. Maynard
turn.text: They would not get a deduction under this calculation.

However, under this Court's decision in Lanning, when one goes to project the disposable income it's conceivable that the debtor could prove that it's known or virtually certain that they will need a new car and that that could be accounted for.
But also the Bankruptcy Code in 1329 allows for modification of a plan, and so when the time arises that their car conks out and they need a new car they can move to modify their plan.
I think--

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: Well, the modification works for chapter 13 but it doesn't work for chapter 7; is that right?

turn.speaker: deanne_e_maynard
turn.label: Ms. Deanne E. Maynard
turn.text: --Well, they make that statement in their reply brief, Your Honor, but I'm not sure exactly what they mean by that, because in chapter 7 this test is being used for a very different purpose.
It's the gateway; it's a presumptive test for abuse.
And so again, our reading makes perfect sense in that context because what you want to know is does this debtor actually have moneys it can prepay its creditors.
Should it be--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --The -- sorry, are you finished?

turn.speaker: deanne_e_maynard
turn.label: Ms. Deanne E. Maynard
turn.text: --I was -- I actually haven't answered the question.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Go ahead.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Why don't you finish answering the question?

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Finish, yes.

turn.speaker: deanne_e_maynard
turn.label: Ms. Deanne E. Maynard
turn.text: So in chapter 7, you want to -- if you decide it's presumptively -- not presumptively abusive, and you stay in chapter 7 and chapter 7 is a liquidation.
There is no ongoing plan.
So I -- all of your nonexempt assets are liquidated, your creditors are paid off, and then you are discharged.
If 3 years from now your car conks out, you're just like you and me; you are not in bankruptcy, you just -- you try to make do.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I think it is -- well, I'm trying to work out what was his point.
And I don't blame him for this.

But trying to figure it out, he says look: This whole thing was written for a different purpose than the IRS and if we start reading all those things from the beginning into the tables we are really going to get into a mess.
For example, we are going to give people deductions when they have lease payments, even though they are not owners when they have lease payments.
The company owns -- not even an ownership expense, but it does say use the lease payment, and then it has all these other things.
So forget it; do a simple thing.
It says ownership expense.
You go to the registry of motor vehicles and you say, is Smith the owner?
And they will tell you, yes or no.
And if the answer is yes, he deducts $471.
Sometimes that's too little, sometimes that's too much.
But once we depart from that, we are really in a nightmare of trying to figure out what all these things mean that were written for other purposes.
So what do you say to that?

turn.speaker: deanne_e_maynard
turn.label: Ms. Deanne E. Maynard
turn.text: I say, Justice Breyer, that there is nothing in the statute or the legislative history that suggests that this was meant to be an overall budget for above-median income debtors.
This was about capping upper discretion and limiting the expenses available as reasonably necessary expenses for above-median income debtors.
And I think that point is made perfectly clear by the fact that you can compare it to what happens now to a below-median income debtor.

A below-median income debtor in the same situation as Petitioner, who owns his car outright, would be allowed no amount as an expense for his vehicle, because he doesn't have an actual expense that's reasonably necessary.

And I think that the 2005 Congress would think it was a senseless result, as they argue here, that Petitioner gets $471, above-median income debtor, the very class of debtors with whom Congress was concerned in the 2005 amendment, to shield from his creditors over the life of the plan when he has no comparable expense.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: What we are talking about is a paradigm of someone -- we are comparing someone who has a $470-a-month car payment and he gets -- and he gets the deduction.
Why is that, in light of the second sentence -- let's see, the third sentence of the statute, which says,
"Notwithstanding any other provision of this clause, the monthly expenses of the debtor shall not include any payments for debts. "
I mean, that would be the car company.
Has that point been litigated?

turn.speaker: deanne_e_maynard
turn.label: Ms. Deanne E. Maynard
turn.text: That sentence is somewhat of a conundrum, Your Honor, and I think that the Court doesn't need to decide the meaning here, because whatever it does, it doesn't get the Petitioner within the Romanette ii calculation, because he has no payment.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: No, but it would -- it would eliminate the anomaly that -- one of the principal anomalies.
There are many anomalies in each position.
It would eliminate one of the principal asymmetries that seems to concern the counsel and the Court.

turn.speaker: deanne_e_maynard
turn.label: Ms. Deanne E. Maynard
turn.text: Well, my understanding of that provision is that it serves two purposes.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: It -- it--

turn.speaker: deanne_e_maynard
turn.label: Ms. Deanne E. Maynard
turn.text: Serves two purposes.
The first is that it makes clear -- in the back of our brief, we have the other necessary expenses from the IRM.
And on -- near the back, page 25a, two of the categories of other necessary expenses are secured or legally perfected debts and unsecured debts.

So I think the -- the otherwise -- the "notwithstanding" sentence makes clear that Romanette ii should not capture those other unsecured debts and secured debts that is the whole purpose of this calculation, to figure out how much money you have to pay those things.

The second purpose the sentence serves is to make sure that there is no double-counting, because Romanette iii, the very next provision in the means test, allows the debtor to claim monthly payments for secured debts.

Now, many car loans are probably secured debts and in our view if you actually have a car loan -- now, remember again, he neither has a car loan, nor a car lease payment, nor any kind of ownership payment.

But if -- if one actually did have a car loan that was secured by the car, which I think is the vast majority of car loans, in our view the debtor expenses nothing for that under Romanette ii, and only the actual amount of that debt under Romanette iii.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: I thought the -- the general position was you get either the actual payment or the 471, of whichever is higher.

turn.speaker: deanne_e_maynard
turn.label: Ms. Deanne E. Maynard
turn.text: Whichever is less.
I think that -- that is my understanding of how the local standards work, Your Honor.

I think, then, as a practical matter, that really will end up only applying to car leases with respect to transportation ownership costs, because I think that the notwithstanding sentence removes secured car loans from Romanette ii and has been calculated under Romanette iii, where there is no comparable cap.

But the point at issue in this case doesn't involve the interaction between Romanette ii and Romanette iii, because no matter how those two things interact, when the debtor has no payment whatsoever, he ought not to be able to claim any car ownership costs, because what we are frying to figure out is: What amount does he reasonably need for his maintenance and support?
And this question is a very important question.
This scenario happens a lot.

In the 2007 study that U.S. Trustees did at Congress's request to -- which Petitioner cites in his reply brief, the average overpayment of a debtor in claiming this transportation ownership expense was $335, which is a lot when you are talking about the standard in the tarp being 471.

There are many debtors who are getting this expense either above their amount or when they have no such expense at all, and so even if the Court doesn't resolve these other issues that are implicated by this case, the decision here is a simple one, which is: This debtor has no applicable monthly expense amount for transportation ownership costs, and he shouldn't be allowed to expense any amount for that.
If there are no further questions, the Respondent requests that the Court would affirm the judgment below.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, Counsel.
Ms. Saharsky?

turn.speaker: nicole_saharsky
turn.label: Ms. Nicole A. Saharsky
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
The only question this Court needs to resolve in this case is whether the vehicle ownership expense is applicable to Petitioner.
The answer is no.
The ownership cost is for loan and lease payments, the cost to acquiring the vehicle, and he just doesn't have any payments of that type.
To allow him to pretend that he does would create absurd results.
He would be able to shield approximately $28,000 from his unsecured creditors, and he would be better off than lower income Chapter 13 debtors.
And we just don't think that that's a result that Congress intended.
We don't--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: And if he pays--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, I -- excuse me, Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: --If he paid a dollar, he would be able to shield $27,999, and you are comfortable with that result.

turn.speaker: nicole_saharsky
turn.label: Ms. Nicole A. Saharsky
turn.text: --Well, that goes to the question of whether the amount in the table is the amount to be used or a cap on actual expenses.
In our view, it is--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: And I understood your brief to say it was the amount -- you get the whole amount, not simply as a cap.

turn.speaker: nicole_saharsky
turn.label: Ms. Nicole A. Saharsky
turn.text: --That's right.
Now, of course, we haven't seen -- the executive office for U.S. Trustees has not seen any $1 payments.
It doesn't know of any such commercially available payments.
It suspects the payments would be--

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: If the point of the $1, Counsel, is to lead to the extreme hypothetical that would flesh out your position, what if it were $10,000 and the amount would give him $30,000?
The trustees have probably seen loans like that.

turn.speaker: nicole_saharsky
turn.label: Ms. Nicole A. Saharsky
turn.text: --What I'm saying, Your Honor, is that there are many circumstances in which an expense amount is a standard amount, but you still need to make a threshold showing that it's applicable to you.

And if I could give the Court one example: When an individual does his Federal income tax forms, you can take a deduction for your dependents, but you can't just take a deduction for any child you have.

You have to take a deduction -- you can take a deduction if the person lives at home with you for more than one year and have you a certain amount of expenses to support them, and that is a standard deduction that you get on your tax forms.
The IRS doesn't ask everyone to figure out their actual costs.
It is the case in real life that there are allowance amounts that are average amounts that are given to people once they meet the criteria.
And that's what we are saying happens here.
Now, that is, again, only a disagreement as to what you do with people who actually have vehicle ownership expenses.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why aren't -- why isn't one of the criteria the provision that says maximum allowances for housing and utilities and transportation, known as the local standards, vary by location and unlike the national standards, the taxpayer is allowed the amount actually spent or the standard, whichever is less?
Why doesn't that apply?

turn.speaker: nicole_saharsky
turn.label: Ms. Nicole A. Saharsky
turn.text: Well, because, Your Honor, in that case it's the IRS commentary we are referring to that is on page 1A of the red brief appendix.
And that -- what that's referring to is, it says the amount actually spent or the standard.
And that's distinguishing between the amount that is actually spent or the standard, which is the standard--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: nicole_saharsky
turn.label: Ms. Nicole A. Saharsky
turn.text: --amount in the table.
Right.

And of course, we look to what -- the text that Congress enacted in the Bankruptcy Code, and that says that the debtor's monthly expenses shall be the debtor's applicable monthly expense amounts specified under the national standards and local standards.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It's not applicable.
It's not applicable if, in fact, you haven't spent that much.
Just as you claim it's not applicable if you have no payment at all.

turn.speaker: nicole_saharsky
turn.label: Ms. Nicole A. Saharsky
turn.text: I think that it would further Congress's purposes to say that you have to -- that you look to the actual costs that the debtor has.

But we just don't think the text goes that far, because it says that if the expense amounts, the category, is applicable to the debtor, that then you use the expense amounts specified under the table.
But--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: No, but the -- but the gravamen of Justice Scalia's question is: Why are you running away from 1A, which is what Respondent's counsel relied on?
And if that were clearly relevant to this statute, it would seem to me to answer the question.
Are you saying we -- we don't look at this because it's just simply an interpretation, it's not a regulation?
What is -- what is -- in your view, what effect do we give to this language that Justice Scalia quoted?
Nothing at all?

turn.speaker: nicole_saharsky
turn.label: Ms. Nicole A. Saharsky
turn.text: --It would not be relevant in the bankruptcy context, in our view, and the reason is because the statutory text refers to the standards.
And in our view, you can look to the IRS commentary to see what the standards mean, what their scope is, as Justice Breyer was discussing with his apples hypothetical.
But this additional language is guidance to IRS agents in tax delinquency cases about how to collect taxes.
As Petitioners--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Suppose we -- suppose we think the word "applicable" is ambiguous and difficult to construe.
Do we then look at this language at 1A, or do you say it is irrelevant in all instance -- in all -- in all respects?

turn.speaker: nicole_saharsky
turn.label: Ms. Nicole A. Saharsky
turn.text: --You -- Your Honor, you could look at this language, but we think that it reflects not the standards, but what -- how the IRS uses the standards in individual cases of tax delinquency.

To the extent that the IRS is defining what the standards are, what the scope of the standards are -- for example, that ownership costs are loan and lease payments -- of course we would think that you would look to that, but this additional guidance to IRS agents we don't think is what Congress meant when it said
"expense amounts specified under the standards. "
But we do think that the text could be read the way you suggest.

turn.speaker: sonia_sotomayor
turn.label: Justice Sonia Sotomayor
turn.text: So then you would be comfortable with a person who owns a house outright who only pays $100 in utilities taking the full amount of the housing and utilities allowable living expenses because that's the amount specified?

turn.speaker: nicole_saharsky
turn.label: Ms. Nicole A. Saharsky
turn.text: Well, the housing and utilities expenses have been broken out into a mortgage and rent component and utilities component.
So in that circumstance we would say the individual only is allowed the utilities component, but it would be the allowance amount that is specified, it would not be this actual amount.
But again, this was a question that was not considered by the courts below.

In fact, the Bankruptcy Appellate Panel said in footnote 20 of its brief, said this question is not in this case, it's not before us whether you use the actual amounts in the table or whether you use the actual amounts.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Ms. Saharsky, I should probably know this, but if you do have amounts that are excluded from the disposable income because of car ownership, in other words, you actually have, in your point of view, expenses, do they have to go to the pay off the car loan or are they available for everybody?
All the creditors?

turn.speaker: nicole_saharsky
turn.label: Ms. Nicole A. Saharsky
turn.text: They are not available for the creditors.

The idea behind this calculation is that there, of course, are secured debts that have priority and then this calculation is used to figure out how much money is left to pay unsecured creditors, and the idea is that the debtor has certain expenses, that he needs to keep money for himself so he can continue with the every day business of life.

For example, the car ownership payment is designed to ensure that a vehicle can still use and have access to a car, and if someone has a loan or lease payment they need to be able to continue making that payment in bankruptcy, but if they don't have any such payment then they don't have this additional need for additional funds.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: If there is more food expense than is allowed, can he decide of the amount that would otherwise go for the car payment that he is going to pay some of that for the food expenses?

turn.speaker: nicole_saharsky
turn.label: Ms. Nicole A. Saharsky
turn.text: Well, certainly the Bankruptcy Court doesn't scrutinize, you know, what happens to that regard.
What it's just trying to do is figure out the disposable income that is available to pay unsecured creditors that the debtor doesn't need.

And I should just note with respect to this question of whether there is an overall budget that the debtor is allowed, you know, that is certainly not the case in any of the other provisions that follow this applicable monthly standards and local standards.
You have the actual other necessary expenses, actual continuation of taking care of chronically ill family members, and Petitioner himself acknowledges that he has to show that he has a car.
So it's not the case that every debtor is just getting some set amount of money to do what they will with.

Congress has referenced the standards, the standards break this out into certain expenses, it says just take the applicable ones and we just don't think it makes sense to interpret applicable in that circumstance.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: Ms. Saharsky, could you explain to me the Government's position on when a debtor with loan and lease payments gets to deduct them under Romanette II?
In other words, this goes back to Justice Kennedy's question, the notwithstanding clause and whether the notwithstanding clause effectively excludes all loan and lease payments from Romanette II?

turn.speaker: nicole_saharsky
turn.label: Ms. Nicole A. Saharsky
turn.text: It does not have that affect, Your Honor.
What it does is to take out the actual debt payments that are part of the other necessary expenses, these are on page 25-A of the red brief that counsel on our side mentioned.
These are other necessary expenses that are actual debt payments and the local and national standards are expense amounts.
We don't think that Congress defined those to be debt payments.
So the function of the payments for debts language, we agree with Respondent's counsel would be twofold.
First, it would excise the other necessary expenses that actually are debt payments, which makes complete sense.

One of them is an unsecured debt payment, and you wouldn't want to consider that one of your expenses because the whole point of the calculation is to figure out how much money you have left to pay unsecured debt.
And then the other function that it serves is in Romanette III because you were getting secured debt payments there to not double-count them in Romanette II.

turn.speaker: elena_kagan
turn.label: Justice Elena Kagan
turn.text: But, in other words, the loan and lease payments don't count as debt for purposes of the notwithstanding clause, they count as expense amounts?

turn.speaker: nicole_saharsky
turn.label: Ms. Nicole A. Saharsky
turn.text: We say that those are expense amounts that are specified, they're not payments for debts.
I should note, because Justice Kennedy asked this question, that this was not something that was relied upon by the courts below.
I don't believe there is any definitive court of appeals opinion that goes through in detail what that provision is designed to do.

So I would urge this Court that it need not resolve it in this case and instead do what the court of appeals did, which is to say that just looking at the plain text, the word applicable means not everybody can get these amounts in the national and local standards and it needs to be someone who actually has those payment amounts.

The whole point of this part of this statute is to figure out what money is available to pay unsecured creditors and it's payments that need to be made for expenses that matter, it's not whether the individual debtor has a car.

I also note just because it came up earlier and is a very important point, that to the extent that the Court only wants to look at the tables to figure out what are ownership costs, are they loan and lease payments.
Just looking at the title of the table, ownership costs, you need to have costs.

Looking at the fact that there are two different ones, there is ownership costs as opposed to operating costs, makes clear that some of the things that Petitioner suggests might be ownership costs are, in fact, operating costs.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, counsel.
Mr. Burke, have you four minutes remaining.

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: Thank you.
The means test knows when to say actual when it wants to say actual.
It didn't say actual in this case, it said applicable.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Burke, would you explain one facet of this case to me.
Given the deduction, the $471 deduction, projected disposable income comes down to $210?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: As opposed to it would be $600 some if you didn't count the $471?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Even though the disposable income figure was $210, the debtor was willing -- the debtor proposed paying $500.
Why did the debtor come up with a $500 figure when projected disposable income without the car ownership would be -- if he gets the car ownership would only be $210?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: This is exactly why our view of the law works.
The means test is a minimum amount.
It's a bottom line quick figure based on standard deductions.
It was $200 based on our calculation if he's given his deduction based on age, location, et cetera.
We then go back to I and J, and J, which is on page 44 of the Joint Appendix, is his current expenses.
And if we look at line 13-A, there is no vehicle payment.
He is not taking $471.
He took his income and expense, the bottom line was 500, he knew he had to pay at least 200, he is willing to pay the 500.
He is not getting a $471 deduction because there is no car payment on his Schedule J.

And if we look at the formula that way, the means test is a general form to give standard deductions, to give us a quick bottom line, and the debtor is either going to pay that amount or more based on his income and expense, and he would pay more if he really didn't have that expense.
So if he didn't have a rent expense of $1,000 a month it would show up on Schedule J that he didn't have 1,000, so his payment would go to $1,500 a month.
That's the good faith that is involved in this case.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It would have to go to 1,500 a month or he, out of the goodness of his heart, would decide to pay that amount?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: He's going to have to pay an amount of at least $200.
It would be hard to confirm a case if he doesn't pay somewhere in that range.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Fine.
So why would we assume, I don't know -- your client is an extraordinarily generous fellow.
I don't think most people when they go through bankruptcy are going to cough up any more than they have to.

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: It's the only way for the form and the law to work.
The means test is a bottom line number.
If you don't have one of those expenses, it shows up on Schedule J and it gives you a number.
If it's higher, we think you should probably pay it or in that range.
If it's lower, Congress isn't saying you get away with it, it says you get out of Chapter 13 if you are not going to pay this amount.
So the formula is just to come up with a bottom line.
Nobody is shielding anything, it's all black and white on his current expenses.
If he doesn't have it, he is not getting it.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: Do you think that the Bankruptcy Code provision freezes the national and local standards to some degree or completely as they existed at the time when the statute was enacted?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: At the time the debtor files, those numbers are frozen.

turn.speaker: samuel_alito_jr
turn.label: Justice Samuel A. Alito, Jr.
turn.text: But the IRS can change, otherwise going forward they could completely change the national and local standards?

turn.speaker: christopher_p_burke
turn.label: Mr. Christopher P. Burke
turn.text: The numbers, but not the structure.
They can do anything they want when they are collecting taxes, but the numbers -- and I think the numbers change on an annual basis.

turn.speaker: john_g_roberts_jr
turn.label: Chief Justice John G. Roberts, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, counsel.
The case is submitted.
